info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 20 at 8:15PM EDT until June 20 at 9:15PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 915 PM EDT THIS EVENING FOR SOUTHWESTERN ROWAN COUNTY... At 815 PM EDT, Rowan County Emergency Management reports new areas of flooding are developing as floodwaves move downstream in the tributaries feeding N Second Creek including, Sill Creek, Back Creek, and Kerr Creek north of Atwell and east of Mount Ulla, including Kerr Mill-Sloan Park. Back Creek Church Rd is currently underwater at Sills Creek. Kerr Creek is currently causing significant flooding of lowlands including residental yards at NC 150. Other potential areas of flooding that may develop over the next 1-2 hours include around White Rd, Lyerly Rd, Upright Rd, Graham Rd, Goodnight Rd, and Sherrills Ford Rd. Drivers are urged to obey all barricades and avoid flooded roadways. Turn Around, Don`t Drown. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Emergency management reported. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Some locations that may continue to experience flash flooding include... Kannapolis, Salisbury, Statesville, Mooresville, Davidson, China Grove, Landis, Enochville, Troutman, Cleveland, Lake Norman State Park, Mount Ulla, Piedmont Research Station and Doolie. Areas of light rainfall are approaching Rowan County. This rainfall is not expected to pose any threats. However, new rounds of heavy rainfall are possible tonight and this could reinvigorate the flood threat given saturated soils and swollen streams. Another round of heavy rainfall is possible on Thursday. Please stay weather aware and be prepared to take action should heavy rain redevelop. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Move to higher ground now. Act quickly to protect your life.
